creator: terry8

content:
General background info which might work for you:

In Windows 10 , 'Settings' > 'Ease of Access', there is 'Automatically hide scrollbars in Windows' option - it might be switched on, so switch it off. This should also force the Firefox browser scrollbars to stay visible. But that is a general Windows OS setting.

Also check the 'Registry Editor' - In windows bottom serch type: Registry Select: 'Registry Editor' You may asked permission to proceed. Navigate to this location: Computer\HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\Desktop\WindowMetrics

Look for these two lines: 'ScrollHeight' and 'ScrollWidth', By default, they may have this negative number: -252 I had the scrollwidth and scrollheight set to: -255

To alter a number: Double click on the word 'ScrollHeight' and it opens a small window. It will say 'Value data:' and this is where you remove the contents and then type in a suitable negative number. You might need to enter: -255 or if you already see a number simlilar to that try something larger such as: -360 Then click on 'OK' Whatever you set for ScrollHeight', you need to also set up for 'ScrollWidth'.

But in Thunderbird, you may want to set this up with specific control: In Thunderbird.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button

It opens in a new tab

  • In top search area type: scrollbar.
  • Look for the following 3 lines (as numbered below) and edit them.

1. 'widget.non-native-theme.scrollbar.size.override' - change number to eg: 50 (you can modify this a suitable size ) 2. 'widget.non-native-theme.scrollbar.style' - change number to 4 3. 'widget.non-native-theme.win.scrollbar.use-system-size' - toggle to say 'false'

  • To edit a number click on the 'pencil' icon
  • Change number and then click on the 'tick' icon to save
  • To toggle from true to false - clickon the far right toggle icon

Once you have those three set up, you can then alter the first one to find a suitable size. On my computer 20 was ok, but it all depends upon what screen resolution and scaling you are using.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
John, I feel your frustration, and I'm sorry that you have it.

You have found the place for support. This is it.

Now, to your problem: At first, you said that you are getting a request to log in "constantly", that you cannot send messages, and that you may not be receiving any messages. Then you wrote that your login to your TekSavvy account fails whenever you start Thunderbird. Is that an accurate description of the problem?

Are you ever able to send and receive any messages?

I asked for a screenshot, but you did not provide one.

In most cases, this problem is just a matter of entering the right settings and credentials in Thundberbird. Somtimes, Thunderbird might not remember a password.

First thing: Can you sign in to TekSavvy webmail with your username and password?

https://mail.teksavvy.com/webmail/

Second thing: Verify that you are using the right settings and credentials in Thunderbird. TekSavvy does not make it easy to find out what settings should be used. All that I could find is old and seems incomplete. So I suggest that you contact TekSavvy (https://www.teksavvy.com/company/contact/) and ask for the settings needed for 1) the incoming server (IMAP or POP, depending on your account type), and 2) the outgoing (SMTP) server.

Then check those settings in Thunderbird. The incoming server settings are in account settings > server settings. The outgoing server settings are in account settings > [click on the account name] > Edit SMTP server.

Please report your findings.
creator: mozilla98

content:
I think your friend is suggesting you create a mailing list of your recipients, and in that case you're only limited by the number allowed by the mail provider, typically 100. The gmail term for TB's mailing list is 'label'. Create a new mailing list by clicking the icon next to the New Contact button in Address Book, name it and close it, then add contacts from the address book by drag and drop onto the list icon.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Thunderbird_:_FAQs_:_Create_Mailing_List

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-create-and-use-mailing-lists-thunderbird

content:
If you do want to see the Folder Pane Header - maybe you have limited vertical space..... You can add the 'Get Messages' and 'New Message' / 'Write' option to the Unified Toolbar. Right click on top Unified Toolbar and select 'Customise' see info: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/unified-toolbar

Once you have those on the Unified Toolbar, you could hide the Folder Pane Toolbar. In fact if you need space above the Message List, you could put the 'Quick Filter' onto the Unified Toolbar and then hide the 'Message List Header' toolbar.

If you need to see the 'Menu Bar' toolbar (File, Edit, View, etc) Menu app icon (3 lines) > View > Toolbars > select 'Menu Bar'

content:
This question sounds like both you and your wife have not been able to get emails.

First - please check all the following so we can be certain nothing else is interfering. Firewall Access Firewall, this might be the default on computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. The Thunderbird program must be set up as an allowed program. Please confirm you have this set up.

Anti-Virus: This might be set up to auto scan any file that gets opened etc, so could be causing an interference when Thunderbird is starting up or even when attempting to download. I would advise that you set up an exemption to not scan your Thunderbird folder that contains all info on profile(s). If you downloaded Thunderbird from the official website : https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ Then the profile will by default be here: C:/Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Another way to check if AV is an issue: Restart computer in 'Safe mode with Networking' mode - please note you will need to use an ethernet cable to connect computer to router as it will not work using wireless connection.

VPN Please check your computer to see if you have enabled a VPN. Many Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and some auto enable it. I use Norton365 and after an update discovered it has auto enabled a VPN which basically caused all kinds of issues. Most servers do not like VPN because it hides the expected IP address, so server blocks access because it thinks you are a hacker. Switch off the VPN or you can create a split tunnelling and set up Thunderbird to use it.

Report back to confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program, AV is not auto scanning your profile, there's no VPN operating.

Now please offer the following information: Q: Are you both using the same computer or different computers ? Q: What OS are you both using? Windows 10, 11, MAC, Linux ? Q: What version of Thunderbird are you both using?

Q: What type of mail account are you and your wife using - Pop or IMAP ? Q: What Anti-Virus have you got installed on computer (s) ?

Please post information so we understand what server you are trying to connect to and what server settings you currently using. Post images that show:

  1. Account Settings > Server Settings
  2. and also the 'Outgoing Server SMTP' Settings

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail & News Accounts' section
  • Either post an image showing all that section or Copy all the dta in that section and paste it into this forum question.

Don't forget to post the info asked by david - image of any error message is important.
creator: Toad-Hall
